name: Strum Pattern Workout
description: A dozen essential strum patterns covering 4/4 and 3/4 time, straight and swing feels, clean and muted techniques.

steps.name: Quarter Note Downs
steps.instructions: The foundation of all strumming. Strum down on every beat with a relaxed wrist. Focus on even volume across all strings and a consistent tempo. Switch chords every two measures.
steps.notes: Slow and steady. This is your warmup — focus on clean chord changes on beat 1.

steps.name: Steady Eighth Notes
steps.instructions: Down on the beat, up on the 'and'. Your arm swings like a pendulum — it never stops moving. Keep the motion smooth and even between down and up strokes.
steps.notes: Every slot is strummed — no gaps. This builds the arm motion that all other patterns depend on.

steps.name: Classic Folk Strum
steps.instructions: The most common strum pattern in popular music: D . D U . U D U (1, 2 &, & 4 &). Your arm still moves on every eighth note — you just miss the strings on beats 1& and 3. Think of it as 'removing' strums from the full eighth-note pattern.
steps.notes: The secret is the missing beat 3. Your arm goes down but doesn't touch the strings.

steps.name: Pop Rock Drive
steps.instructions: A driving pattern that accents beats 1 and 1&: D D . U D U . U. The two quick downs at the start give it energy, while the rests on 2 and 4 create space. Common in pop-rock and singer-songwriter music.
steps.notes: The double down at the start (D D) is the signature of this pattern. Make those two strums crisp.

steps.name: Reggae Offbeat
steps.instructions: Strum ONLY on the offbeats (the 'ands'). Rest on every downbeat. This is the classic reggae 'skank'. Use short, clipped upstrokes — lift your fretting hand slightly right after each strum to mute the strings.
steps.notes: The click on the downbeat is your rest. Strum only when you hear silence between clicks.

steps.name: Muted Funk
steps.instructions: Alternate between clean down strums and muted (ghost) up strums. On the muted strums, lightly release fretting pressure so the strings produce a percussive 'chk' sound. This creates a tight, rhythmic groove.
steps.notes: The muted strums are quieter but just as important. They're the glue that holds the groove together.

steps.name: Funky Ghost Notes
steps.instructions: A more complex funk pattern: clean down on 1, muted up on 1&, rest on 2, muted up on 2&, then repeat. The rests create a syncopated, bouncy feel. Keep your strumming arm moving constantly.
steps.notes: This pattern is all about dynamics. The clean strums pop out against the ghost notes.

steps.name: Punk Downstrokes
steps.instructions: All downstrokes on every eighth note at high speed. This is physically demanding — it builds right-hand endurance. Keep your wrist loose and don't tense your forearm. If your arm burns, you're gripping too hard.
steps.notes: Speed comes from the wrist, not the elbow. Small, quick motions. Drop the BPM if you tense up.

steps.name: Blues Shuffle
steps.instructions: The classic folk strum pattern with a swing feel. The 'and' beats come late, creating a triplet-based shuffle groove. Don't try to force the swing — let the metronome guide you. It should feel lazy and relaxed.
steps.notes: Swing = the 'and' beats are delayed. Think 'da-dum, da-dum' instead of 'da-da, da-da'. Listen to the metronome's uneven eighth notes.

steps.name: Swing Country
steps.instructions: Same pattern as the Classic Folk Strum, but with a light swing (62%). This subtle shuffle transforms a straight folk strum into a country groove. Compare this to step 3 — same arm motion, completely different feel.
steps.notes: Light swing (62%) is subtle — the offbeats are only slightly late. This is the feel behind most country and rockabilly music.

steps.name: Waltz Strum
steps.instructions: Three beats per measure: a strong beat 1 followed by lighter beats on 2 and 3. Accent the first beat of each measure. This is the foundation of all 3/4 time playing — waltzes, many ballads, and folk songs.
steps.notes: Feel the 'ONE two three, ONE two three' pulse. Beat 1 is the anchor.

steps.name: Waltz Folk Pattern
steps.instructions: A 3/4 pattern with eighth notes: D . D U D U. Down on 1, skip 1&, then down-up on beats 2 and 3. This gives the waltz more momentum and flow — common in folk, Celtic, and country waltz styles.
steps.notes: The rest on 1& creates a brief pause that makes beat 2 feel like it 'falls' in. This is what gives folk waltzes their lilting quality.
